title: From Lived Experience to Systemic Change: The ACT Story
context_note: This brief provides structure for the ACT origin story article. The actual content MUST be developed with direct founder input - this is not content that can be generated autonomously. The brief serves as a framework for that conversation.

why_this_story_matters: Origin stories build trust and authenticity
Lived experience credibility is central to ACT's identity
Demonstrates the journey from personal pain to systemic change
Helps readers understand WHY ACT exists, not just WHAT it does
Positions JusticeHub within a larger narrative of transformation
audiences: Young people and families seeking to understand who's behind this
Media seeking the human story behind the platform

questions_for_founder: What personal experience with the justice system shaped this work?
What was the moment of realisation that systemic change was needed?
What did you see that others weren't seeing?
What was broken in how the system treated you or others?
the_lived_experience.note: This section requires authentic founder voice - cannot be generated

questions_for_founder: When did the idea for ACT first emerge?
What was the earliest seed that eventually became this ecosystem?
Who else was part of the early conversations?
What resources did you start with? What did you lack?
How did ACT evolve from initial idea to current form?
What pivots or major decisions shaped the direction?
When did JusticeHub become a focus?
How did the LCAA method emerge?
When did the farm/land-based practice become central?

from_brand_docs.current_identity: A regenerative innovation ecosystem partnering with marginalised—especially First Nations—communities to dismantle extractive systems
from_brand_docs.metaphor: Like a tractor's power take-off (PTO), we transfer resources, knowledge, and capacity to community-led initiatives—we hand over the keys

questions_for_founder: Where do the core values come from?
Why 'radical humility'? What taught you that?
Why the commitment to 'designing for obsolescence'?
How did the 40% profit-sharing commitment emerge?

values: Radical Humility: We don't have all the answers, but we're cultivating solutions together
Decentralised Power: Communities lead; we support. Every tool has a sunset clause
Creativity as Disruption: Revolution starts with imagination
Uncomfortable Truth-telling: Name extractive systems and work to dismantle them

questions_for_founder: How did the focus on First Nations partnership emerge?
What did you learn about Indigenous data sovereignty?
How do you approach truth-telling about colonisation and extraction?
What has working on Jinibara Country taught you?
first_nations_partnership.note: This section should be reviewed by First Nations partners before publication

questions_for_founder: Why is JusticeHub the flagship platform at this moment?
What do you hope JusticeHub will achieve?
How does JusticeHub embody ACT's values?
What's the vision for JusticeHub's future?

structure.approach: Open with a vivid moment - either from founder's experience or from someone ACT has worked with. NOT generic - must be specific and authentic.
What the founder saw/experienced that others weren't seeing. The systemic failure. The extraction.
The moment or period when ACT began to take shape. Not polished - show the messy early stages.
How LCAA and the values crystallized through practice, not theory.
How Jinibara Country and the farm became central to the practice.
Brief mention of projects (Empathy Ledger, JusticeHub, Goods on Country, etc.) as expressions of the vision.
Position JusticeHub as the current flagship - why this, why now.
What ACT is inviting readers into. Not a donation ask - an invitation to participate in systemic change.

tone_guidance.voice: Authentic, not polished. Grounded, not promotional. Humble, not heroic.
do: Use first person where appropriate (founder's voice)
Include specific details that prove authenticity
Acknowledge mistakes and learnings along the way
Show the messy reality, not a clean hero's journey
Connect personal story to systemic analysis
avoid: Savior narrative - this is about communities, not one person
Making the founder the hero instead of communities

essential: Founder review and approval - this is their story
Fact-checking of any specific claims or dates
First Nations partner review of Indigenous partnership section
recommended: Early community member review for accuracy
Legal review if any sensitive details about justice system experience

process_recommendation.step_1: Share this brief with founder for initial reaction
process_recommendation.step_2: Schedule conversation to gather authentic content
